bioghist.p: The National Woman's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU) was founded in Cleveland, Ohio, in November 1874. It grew out of the "Woman's Crusade" of the winter of 1873-1874. Members advanced their cause by entering saloons, singing, praying, and urging saloonkeepers to stop selling alcohol. Local chapters were called "Unions" and were largely autonomous, but closely linked to the state unions and national headquarters. The Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Kaysville, Utah, was one of these local chapters.

scopecontent.p: This is a volume of minutes of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Kaysville, 1893-1899. The minutes record the election of officers, papers read at meetings, and planning of events and programs. The volume includes minutes of "mother's meetings," at which works on child rearing were read. The collection also includes a printed copy of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Kaysville's constitution, several programs, and a list of members.
